questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office with a 3-week history of dark brown urine. He also complains of a cough productive of pinkish sputum that started around the same time. Review of systems reveals loss of appetite, fatigue, and 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the last month. He has had no oral ulcers, joint pain, or rashes. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral wheezing. There is 2+ peripheral pitting edema. Serum creatinine is 1.3 mg/dL. Complete blood count and urinalysis results are shown below. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral nodular densities. Serum c-ANCA is positive. Renal biopsy is shown below. Which of the following additional findings are most likely to be found on further evaluation?

choices.text: History of allergic rhinitis and asthma
Blanching lesions on skin and mucous membranes

questions.solution:
This patient has nephritic syndrome, characterized by hematuria, mild proteinuria, edema, red blood cell (RBC) casts and dysmorphic RBCs. The presence of constitutional symptoms (fatigue, loss of appetite, fever and weight loss), together with hemoptysis, nodular densities on chest x-ray, and crescent formation on renal biopsy, confirms the diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).  

GPA, formerly called Wegener granulomatosis, is an immune-mediated vasculitis associated with the formation of proteinase 3 antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA). These autoantibodies against neutrophil granule proteins are the hallmark of GPA, though their exact role in causing disease remains unclear. The condition usually manifests in older adults with constitutional symptoms, recurrent sinusitis, cough, hemoptysis and nephritic syndrome. Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia, leukocytosis and positive c-ANCA on serology. Chest x-ray reveals nodular densities suggestive of necrosis and cavitation.  

Definitive diagnosis requires biopsy of the involved organs. Common findings include leukocytoclastic vasculitis (cutaneous), deposition of fibrin and C3 in glomeruli in the form of a crescent as indicated by the black arrows (renal), and granulomatous inflammation (lungs).  



Treatment involves immunosuppression, often involving glucocorticoids combined with either cyclophosphamide or rituximab.

Option Analysis

✅ History of recurrent sinopulmonary infections:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive hepatitis C virus serology:
Incorrect: Positive hepatitis C virus serology is associated with mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome, which is a small-vessel vasculitis that usually presents with palpable purpura, arthralgias, and peripheral neuropathy. Though immune complex deposition can lead to nephritic syndrome, biopsy findings usually show glomerular basement membrane thickening and subendothelial deposits, not crescent formation.
❌ History of allergic rhinitis and asthma:
Incorrect: History of atopy (asthma) is usually seen in patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome), which usually presents with nephritic syndrome, skin nodules, purpura, and/or wrist drop (peripheral neuropathy). Laboratory findings include eosinophilia and p-ANCA seropositivity. This diagnosis is unlikely given this patient's normal eosinophil count and c-ANCA seropositivity.
❌ History of recurrent genital ulcerations:
Incorrect: Recurrent genital ulcerations are usually seen in Behçet syndrome, which is also a small-vessel vasculitis. However, it usually presents with recurrent aphthous ulcers, ocular pain (uveitis) and tender bumps on the shin (erythema nodosum), which are not seen in this patient.
❌ Blanching lesions on skin and mucous membranes:
Incorrect: Blanching lesions on the skin and mucous membranes can be seen in hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (also called Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome). The condition usually presents with recurrent epistaxis or hemorrhagic stroke (due to arteriovenous malformations). Although hematuria can be seen, dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs), RBC casts, and nodular densities on chest x-ray would be atypical.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status and flank pain. The patient was found unconscious on a sidewalk by a bystander who called EMS. The patient was provided with intravenous fluids en route, after which his mental status improved. Upon initial assessment, the patient endorses left flank pain radiating to the groin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates dry mucous membranes. The patient’s eyes open spontaneously, and he is oriented to time and place but not to person. Initial laboratory studies are shown. During the first six hours of admission, urine output is 40 mL.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  3.6 mEq/L 
 Chloride  99 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  18 mEq/L 
 Serum creatinine  2.8 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Sediment  Granular “muddy brown” casts and envelope shaped crystals 
 Arterial blood gas (ABG) 
 pH  7.2 
 Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2)  40 mmHg 
 Partial pressure of oxygen (pO2)  85 mmHg 

 Which of the following additional laboratory findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Dysmorphic red blood cells on urine microscopy

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with acute renal failure (oliguria and rising creatinine) and granular casts on urine microscopy is consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN). In addition, this patient’s lab work demonstrates a high anion gap metabolic acidosis and envelope shaped (oxalate) crystals on urinalysis. Together, these findings are consistent with ethylene glycol poisoning--a toxic alcohol found in antifreeze that is often ingested as a substitute for alcohol.  

Ethylene glycol is metabolized to glycolic acid, which causes direct tubular damage, and oxalic acid, which crystallizes and obstructs the renal tubules. Together, these effects result in acute tubular necrosis and intrarenal azotemia. Intrarenal azotemia is characterized by tubular dysfunction, impaired reabsorption of sodium, increased urinary sodium (>40 mEq/L) and increased FENa(>2%). Urea reabsorption is also impaired, causing BUN:Cr to fall below 15. Failure of water reabsorption dilutes the urine, decreasing osmolality to <350 mOsm/kg.  

Urinalysis demonstrates granular “muddy brown” casts of sloughed tubular cells, which are pathognomonic for ATN. Histologically, ATN is characterized by loss of tubular epithelial cells’ nuclei, tubular dilation and epithelial cell vacuolization.  

Option Analysis

✅ Urine osmolality <350 mOsm/kg:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) < 1%:
Incorrect: FENa <1% is seen in prerenal azotemia, where renal tubular function remains intact, causing increased sodium reabsorption due to the activation of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Prerenal azotemia occurs secondary to any process that decreases renal perfusion. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with ethylene glycol poisoning, a type of intrarenal acute kidney injury. 
❌ Hydronephrosis:
Incorrect: Hydronephrosis occurs secondary to obstruction of urinary outflow from the kidneys. Although it can present with increased creatinine levels and oliguria, the findings of increased anion gap metabolic acidosis and granular casts make an intrarenal cause more likely. 
❌ BUN:Cr > 20:
Incorrect: BUN:Cr >20 is observed in prerenal azotemia, as the kidneys reabsorb more urea compared to creatinine. In intrarenal azotemia, however, the kidneys are unable to reabsorb urea due to damaged renal tubular cells, resulting in BUN:Cr <20.  
❌ Dysmorphic red blood cells on urine microscopy:
Incorrect: Dysmorphic red blood cells on urine microscopy are observed in glomerular pathology (e.g. nephritic syndrome). The distortion of red blood cells occurs as they pass through damaged glomeruli. This condition is accompanied by proteinuria and formation of red blood cell casts.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old female presents to the emergency department with worsening lower extremity edema. In addition, her urine has appeared more foamy than usual. Past medical history includes HIV, hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and intravenous heroin use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 157/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is noted to have 2+ peripheral edema of the lower extremities and acanthosis nigricans over the neck. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. A urinalysis is notable for 4+ protein and negative for blood. The patient subsequently undergoes a renal biopsy with the light microscopy finding as below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia     

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of heroin use and HIV presents with clinical features concerning nephrotic syndrome. The biopsy and light microscopy findings demonstrate segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis due to deposition of lipids and proteins within the glomerulus, which is consistent with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.   

 Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in patients of African-American and Hispanic descent. The underlying cause of the disease is not well-established, but is associated with multiple comorbidities including HIV, sickle cell disease, heroin use, obesity, recent interferon treatment, and congenital malformations.   

The disease only affects some glomeruli and particular segments of the glomeruli, hence the nomenclature. Light microscopy will demonstrate segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis, while immunofluorescence is generally negative but will sometimes stain positive for C3, C1, or IgM. Electron microscopy will typically demonstrate podocyte foot effacement, similar to minimal change disease.  

Treatment consists of a trial of corticosteroid therapy. Unfortunately, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis has an inconsistent response to corticosteroids, and some patients may progress to chronic kidney disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Minimal change disease :
Incorrect: Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and is usually idiopathic. Light microscopy findings in these patients are usually normal, although lipid can sometimes be seen in the proximal convoluted tubule. In contrast, this patient’s biopsy result shows segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis.
❌ Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis :
Incorrect: On light microscopy, patients with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis can present with a crescent moon-shaped glomeruli. The crescent consists of fibrin and plasma proteins. In contrast, this patient’s biopsy result shows segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis.
❌ Diabetic glomerulonephropathy :
Incorrect: Light microscopy findings for diabetic glomerulonephropathy include mesangial expansion, glomerular basement membrane thickening, and characteristic Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. No Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules are present on this patient biopsy result.
❌ Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis :
Incorrect: This disease often occurs in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus and demonstrates wire looping on light microscopy.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old Hispanic woman comes to the office because of red-colored urine. She first noticed the change in color 2 days ago. Medical history is significant for several years of joint pains. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral periorbital edema and ulcerative lesions on the palate. Laboratory results are as follows:


After further workup, renal biopsy is performed (shown below).

Reproduced from:

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This woman with nephritic syndrome (hematuria, hypertension, periorbital edema, red blood cell casts) together with biopsy findings of glomerular proliferation and capillary wall thickening most likely has diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN). This patient’s DPGN is likely secondary to an undiagnosed case of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), as indicated by the history of chronic joint pains, ulcerative palatal lesions, and thrombocytopenia.  

DPGN is mostly associated with SLE, an autoimmune condition with higher prevalence in women of Asian, African-Americans and Hispanic descent. Renal involvement (lupus nephritis) is common and is one of the most common causes of death in patients with SLE. It is a result of type III hypersensitivity reaction (HSR), whereby anti-DNA antibodies attack and form immune complexes (ICs) with DNA, the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), and the mesangium. These IC deposits then cause complement activation, inflammation, and glomerular damage, resulting in nephritic syndrome.



Reproduced from:

Lupus nephritis is classified into different types on the basis of histological pattern of glomerular injury. DPGN is the most common and most severe form and is defined as >50% involvement of glomeruli in both kidneys. Histologically, DPGN is characterized by areas of cellular proliferation (arrows) and capillary wall thickening that appears as “wire-looping” (arrowheads). Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular IC deposits. On electron microscopy, it appears as subendothelial IC deposits.



Option Analysis

❌ Normal serum C3 level  :
Incorrect: The subendothelial and mesangial immune complex deposits seen in the biopsy results here result in activation of the complement system, which results in the influx of neutrophils and mononuclear cells, causing inflammation. This utilization leads to decreased serum C3 levels, as the complement activation in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) occurs predominantly via the alternative pathway.
❌ Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies:
Incorrect: Serum anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies are commonly seen in Goodpasture syndrome. This condition is a pulmonary-renal syndrome that usually presents with hemoptysis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Biopsy findings include crescent shaped deposition in glomeruli (not a wire-looping pattern, as seen in this patient).
❌ Increased eosinophil count:
Incorrect: Eosinophilia is usually seen in acute interstitial nephritis, which is typically associated with fever, rash, sterile pyuria, and white blood cell casts -- none of which are seen in this patient.
✅ Anti-double stranded DNA antibodies (anti-dsDNA):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies:
Incorrect: Serum antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with certain vasculitides (e.g. granulomatosis with polyangiitis). Their typical renal manifestation is RPGN that is histologically characterized by crescent formation in glomeruli. Though RPGN can also sometimes be seen in other classes of lupus nephritis, the biopsy findings of this patient are diffuse glomerular capillary wall thickening, which is indicative of another condition.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fatigue, decreased appetite, and muscle weakness. Past medical history includes chronic migraines, hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux, and a recent episode of podagra. Current medications include topiramate, lisinopril, acetazolamide, omeprazole, and probenecid. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 96/66 mmHg. Arterial blood gas and laboratory testing are obtained, and the results are shown below.



Which of the following medications most likely contributed to this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypovolemia, hyperkalemia, urine pH < 5.5, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. She has a type 4 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) secondary to ACE inhibitor (lisinopril) use.



Type 4 RTA is due to aldosterone deficiency or aldosterone resistance in the collecting ducts, which affects both the principal and alpha intercalated cells. Causes of aldosterone deficiency include Addison disease, ACE inhibitors, aldosterone receptor blockers (ARBs), diabetic nephropathy, and NSAIDs. Causes of aldosterone resistance include potassium sparing diuretics and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).    

Aldosterone deficiency or resistance decreases Na+/K+ ATPase activity in principal cells, leading to hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. Likewise, reduced H+ ATPase activity in α-intercalated cells decreases hydrogen excretion and causes a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.  

Normally, the urine is buffered by ammonia (NH3). Ammonia needs to bind with hydrogen ions in order to become trapped in the collecting tubules as ammonium (NH4+). In type 4 RTA, impaired hydrogen secretion leads to less trapping. As a result, the small amounts of hydrogen that do enter the urine are able to significantly affect pH. This explains why urine pH is generally below 5.5 in patients with type 4 RTA.



Option Analysis

❌ Probenecid:
Incorrect: Probenecid can prevent gout by inhibiting resorption of uric acid in the proximal convoluted tubule. However, it would not contribute to the development of this patient’s hyperkalemic (type 4) renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which typically presents with metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and urine pH < 5.5.
❌ Acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase in the proximal convoluted tubule and can result in a proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis. In contrast, this patient has metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and urine pH < 5.5, which is more consistent with a hyperkalemic (type 4) renal tubular acidosis.
✅ Lisinopril:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is a beta blocker that can cause hyperkalemia, but it would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis. In contrast, this patient’s history of ACE inhibitor use makes hyperkalemic (type 4) renal tubular acidosis a more likely explanation for her symptoms.
❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that can cause interstitial nephritis, which presents with fever, rash, hematuria, and pyuria. It would not cause the combination of metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and reduced urine pH. Instead, this combination is more likely due to hyperkalemia (type 4) renal tubular acidosis triggered by ACE inhibitor use.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of a new-onset rash. She was recently diagnosed with bacterial sinusitis and started on amoxicillin. She also reports mild joint pain for the past three days. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for systemic lupus erythematosus. She is afraid that she might have developed the same condition. She does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash. No costovertebral tenderness or joint effusion is present. Her serum creatinine is 2 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2-5 erythrocytes/hpf, numerous white blood cell casts, eosinophiluria, and negative leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Acute interstitial nephritis due to amoxicillin
Acute glomerulonephritis due to bacterial sinusitis
Bacterial infection of the renal interstitium

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with diffuse maculopapular rash following the consumption of amoxicillin in combination with urinalysis findings of hematuria, white blood cell casts and eosinophiluria is consistent with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN).  

Other adverse effects of penicillin include hypersensitivity reactions, which can present with urticaria, severe pruritus, fever, joint swelling, hemolytic anemia, renal failure, and anaphylaxis. Around five to ten percent of patients will manifest a reaction ranging from mild to severe, or even life-threatening with repeated use.  

Penicillins are structurally similar to each other and other beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g. cephalosporins) and there could be cross-reactivity. Nausea and diarrhea may occur with oral penicillin, especially with ampicillin. Gastrointestinal upsets may be caused by direct irritation or by overgrowth of Gram-positive organisms or yeasts. Ampicillin has been implicated in pseudomembranous colitis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Acute interstitial nephritis due to amoxicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute glomerulonephritis due to bacterial sinusitis:
Incorrect: Glomerulonephritis presents with red blood cell casts in the urine instead of white cell casts. Moreover, fluid retention and hypertension are usually present. It can occur 1-2 weeks after the resolution of streptococcal pharyngitis or skin infection. No association with bacterial sinusitis is observed.
❌ Renal atheroemboli:
Incorrect: Thromboemboli primarily occurs in patients with atrial arrhythmias, a prior myocardial infarction, or can be iatrogenic, usually induced by angiography/cardiovascular surgery. They tend to produce complete arterial occlusion and renal infarction, leading to flank pain, hematuria, and an elevated lactate dehydrogenase with relatively normal transaminases. This is an unlikely cause of hematuria in this patient.
❌ Bacterial infection of the renal interstitium:
Incorrect: Bacterial infection of renal interstitium (pyelonephritis) usually presents with fever, chill, flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness. A diffuse maculopapular rash is usually not seen.
❌ Cutaneous flare of SLE:
Incorrect: Cutaneous manifestations of SLE include a malar and discoid rash, unlike the diffuse maculopapular rash seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of left flank pain radiating to the groin. The pain started two hours ago, is sharp, and is rated by the patient as a 10/10. The patient has hematuria but no dysuria or urgency. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows no costovertebral angle tenderness. Plain radiograph of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 4 mm calcified density at the level of the lower left sacrum, just above the level of the vesicoureteric junction. This patient’s groin pain is most likely referred from the involvement of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with flank pain radiating to the groin and radiographic evidence of an opacity in the pelvis, along the course of ureter, is consistent with ureteric colic/calculus.    

A ureteric calculus is the presence of a solid stone in the urinary tract, formed from minerals within the urine. These can obstruct urinary flow, causing renal colic (an acute and severe loin pain) and haematuria. There are three locations where the ureters are at their narrowest and, therefore, where a stone is more likely to become stuck: 
  •  Ureteropelvic junction 
  •  Pelvic brim 
  •  Where the ureter enters the bladder 
Nervous supply to the ureters is delivered via the renal, testicular/ovarian, and hypogastric plexuses. Sensory fibers from the ureters enter the spinal cord at T11-L2 with ureteric pain referred to those dermatomal areas. 
  •  Pain from upper ureteral stones tends to radiate to the flank and lumbar areas.  
  •  Mid-ureteral calculi cause pain that radiates anteriorly and caudally.  
  •  Distal ureteral stones cause pain that tends to radiate into the groin or testicle in the male or labia majora in the female because the pain is referred from the ilioinguinal (L1) or genitofemoral nerves (L1-L2). 


Option Analysis

❌ Subcostal :
Incorrect: The subcostal nerve is the anterior division of the twelfth thoracic nerve. It communicates with the iliohypogastric nerve and gives a branch to the pyramidalis muscle. It also gives off a lateral cutaneous branch that supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the hip. Its involvement would not cause groin pain.  
❌ Iliohypogastric :
Incorrect: The iliohypogastric nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies sensation to skin over the lateral gluteal and hypogastric regions and motor to the internal oblique and transverse abdominal muscles. It’s involvement would not cause groin pain seen in this patient.  
✅ Ilioinguinal :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sciatic :
Incorrect: Sciatic nerve pain typically affects one or more regions in the low back, thigh, leg, and foot but not the groin.  
❌ Pelvic splanchnic:
Incorrect: Pelvic splanchnic nerves are splanchnic nerves that arise from sacral spinal nerves S2, S3,  and S4 to provide parasympathetic innervation to the hindgut, urinary bladder, and sphincter.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to acute flank pain and hematuria that began 3-hours ago. He has had several similar episodes in the past 2 years. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Family history is notable for the patient’s father experiencing similar symptoms. Intravenous hydration, analgesia, and potassium bicarbonate are administered, and the patient’s condition resolves within a few hours. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on urinalysis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute flank pain and hematuria, which are common symptoms of nephrolithiasis. In light of similar episodes in his father, the most likely diagnosis is hereditary cystinuria.  

Hereditary cystinuria is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by a defect in the proximal convoluted tubule cystine-reabsorbing transporter, leading to cystinuria. Since cystine is a poorly soluble amino acid, it precipitates to form stones. This defect also results in poor reabsorption of the amino acids ornithine, lysine, and arginine.  

Symptoms typically begin in childhood. Diagnosis can be made by identifying a positive family history of cystinuria, analyzing the kidney stone after it has been expelled, or identifying hexagonal cystine crystals on urinalysis. A cyanide-nitroprusside test can be used when the stone is not available for analysis and crystals are not visualized in the urine. The addition of cyanide-nitroprusside to urine with cystine induces a purple color change.  

Treatment consists of high fluid intake, dietary modification (low sodium and protein intake), and urinary alkalinization (potassium bicarbonate). In patients who fail initial therapy, thiol-containing drugs such as tiopronin or D-penicillamine, can be used. In cases where large stones form, surgical intervention may be necessary.


Option Analysis

✅ Retrieved from:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retrieved from::
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with uric acid crystals, which can be rhomboid or rosette shape. Uric acid stones can be found in conditions that lead to increased uric acid production (e.g., gout, myeloproliferative disorders) as well as chronic diarrhea (due to bicarbonate loss). In contrast, this patient has no history of such conditions.
❌ Retrieved from::
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) stones, which have a coffin lid shape. These stones can be found in the setting of infection by urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Enterobacter. In contrast, this patient has no history of urinary tract infections.
❌ Retrieved from::
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stone. They present with envelope-shaped or dumbbell-shaped crystals. These stones can be found in conditions such as ethylene glycol (antifreeze) ingestion, vitamin C overconsumption, hypocitraturia, and malabsorption (e.g. Crohn disease). This patient’s medical history and family history favor another diagnosis.
❌ Retrieved from::
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with calcium  oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stone. They present with envelope-shaped or dumbbell-shaped crystals. These stones can be found in conditions such as ethylene glycol (antifreeze) ingestion, vitamin C overconsumption, hypocitraturia, and malabsorption (e.g. Crohn's disease). This patient’s medical history and family history favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male comes to the emergency department due to acute onset of right flank pain and hematuria. Since symptom onset, the patient has had persistent nausea and vomited twice. Medical history is significant for Crohn disease diagnosed 5 years ago. During the past month, the patient suffered from multiple episodes of diarrhea. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast is performed and reveals an 8 mm stone lodged in the right ureter. The patient is given IV fluids and doxazosin. A few hours later, the patient passes the stone. Microscopic analysis reveals that the stone is composed of purely uric acid. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to this patient’s stone formation?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with uric acid nephrolithiasis following multiple bouts of diarrhea due to Crohn disease. Uric acid stones account for 5-10 % of urinary tract stones. Uric acid crystals are typically diamond or barrel-shaped and yellow to orange-brown in color. Of note, uric acid stones are radiolucent and cannot be observed on plain radiographs.  

There are three factors that promote the formation of uric acid stones:
  • High urine uric acid concentration - gout, myeloproliferative disorders  
  • Acidic urine pH  
  • Low urine volume / dehydration - common in hot, arid climates
Chronic diarrhea leads to bicarbonate loss in the stool and volume depletion, which promotes uric acid supersaturation as well as acidic urine pH. The low urine pH shifts the relatively soluble urate salt into insoluble uric acid (H+ + Urate-  ↔  Uric acid). This change leads to supersaturation and stone formation.



Option Analysis

❌ Increased uric acid production:
Incorrect: Increased uric acid production, as seen in conditions such as gout or the myeloproliferative disorders, promotes uric acid stone formation by supersaturation. However, this patient has no history of such conditions.
❌ Infection by urease positive bacteria:
Incorrect: Infection by urease positive bacteria (e.g. Proteus mirabilis) contributes to the formation of struvite stones (magnesium ammonium phosphate), not uric acid stones.
❌ Elevated serum calcium level:
Incorrect: Elevated serum calcium can be seen in conditions such as hyperparathyroidism. It leads to increased filtration of calcium through the kidneys, which promotes the formation of calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones. In contrast, elevated serum calcium would not contribute to the formation of uric acid stones.
✅ Acidic urine pH:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased intestinal oxalate absorption:
Incorrect: Patients with Crohn disease or other conditions affecting the ileum are at risk of developing calcium oxalate kidney stones due to fat malabsorption. Under normal conditions, oxalate binds calcium in the gut and is excreted via stool. When fat malabsorption occurs, the excess fat binds to calcium, making it less available to bind oxalate. As a result, more oxalate is absorbed by the body, thus predisposing patients to developing calcium oxalate stones. However, elevated serum oxalate levels would not contribute to the formation of uric acid stones.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the outpatient clinic because of intermittent left flank pain that has been ongoing for the past two weeks. She has noticed blood in her urine on a few occasions. Moreover, the pain has become more severe. She works as a personal trainer. Family and medical history are unremarkable. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 80/minute, respiratory rate is 16/minute, and blood pressure is 130/95 mm Hg. An x-ray is ordered and shown below:

Retrieved from:

Which of the following best describes the composition of this pathological structure?
questions.solution:
This patient has fever, flank pain, and hematuria, a classic presentation of nephrolithiasis.  

Struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) accounts for approximately 70% of staghorn calculi, which appear as branching calcified densities overlying the renal outline. The stones are radiopaque and visualized on imaging because they are usually mixed with calcium phosphate.  

These kidney stones typically occur in the setting of an infection by urease-positive bacteria. These include Proteus, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Enterobacter. Urease-producing bacteria break down urinary urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide. The ammonia makes the urine more alkaline, thereby reducing the solubility of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate. These substances then precipitate and form stones.  

Treatment involves eradicating the underlying infection and surgical removal of the stone. Microscopic analysis of the patient’s urine and stone will show coffin lid shaped crystals.  



Retrieved from:


Retrieved from:

Option Analysis

❌ Brushite:
Incorrect: Brushite, also termed calcium monohydrogen phosphate, is a type of calcium phosphate kidney stone. Calcium containing stones are radiopaque and can be visualized on plain radiograph. However, they would rarely take the shape of a staghorn calculi.
❌ Calcium oxalate:
Incorrect: Calcium oxalate accounts for about 80% of renal stones. Many conditions can predispose patients to developing calcium oxalate stones. These include ethylene glycol (antifreeze) ingestion, vitamin C overconsumption, hypocitraturia, and malabsorption (e.g. Crohn disease). Calcium oxalate stones are radio-opaque and can be visualized on plain radiograph. However, they would rarely take the shape of a staghorn calculi.
✅ Ammonium magnesium phosphate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uric acid:
Incorrect: Uric acid stones are radiolucent and would not appear on an x-ray. Uric acid stones account for 5-10% of all stones. Dehydration, acidic urine, and increased uric acid levels promote their formation. Additionally, chronic diarrhea, which leads to loss of bicarbonate via feces and lowered urine pH, also facilitates uric acid stone formation.
❌ Cystine:
Incorrect: Cystine stones are seen in patients with hereditary cystinuria, a genetic condition in which the cystine-reabsorbing proximal convoluted tubule transporter loses function. This defect causes increased urinary cystine excretion and cystine nephrolithiasis. Although cystinuria can also cause staghorn calculi, it usually manifests with symptoms in childhood, as well as a positive family history.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to severe right flank pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting for the past 2 hours. He has never had such pain before. Medical history is significant for hypertension. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 25 years. An abdominal ultrasound is obtained and successfully visualizes a stone in the right ureter. Appropriate measurements are taken, and the patient eventually passes the stone. Microscopic analysis of the patient’s urine reveals wedge-shaped crystals. Which of the following conditions would most likely favor the formation of this type of stone over calcium oxalate stones?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. He most likely has nephrolithiasis. Other symptoms of nephrolithiasis include hematuria, dysuria, and urinary urgency. The urinalysis shows wedge-shaped crystals, favoring the diagnosis of calcium phosphate stones.  

The most common type of kidney stone is calcium oxalate, which accounts for approximately 80% of cases. Most risk factors are common to both types of calcium stones (see table below), However, high urinary oxalate levels favor the formation of calcium oxalate stones, whereas high urine pH (pH > 6.5) favors the formation of calcium phosphate stones. In contrast, calcium oxalate stone formation is not affected by urine pH.  



Option Analysis

❌ Low urine volume:
Incorrect: Low urine volume is a risk factor for all kinds of renal stones including calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate, uric acid, and cysteine. The rationale behind this risk factor is that low urine volume causes supersaturation of substances filtered by the kidney.
❌ High urine calcium:
Incorrect: High urine calcium is associated with both calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stone formation
❌ Low urine citrate:
Incorrect: Low urine citrate is associated with both calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones.  Citrate decreases urinary supersaturation of calcium salts by forming soluble complexes with calcium ions, thus preventing crystal growth and aggregation.  
✅ High urine pH:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ High urine oxalate:
Incorrect: High urine oxalate is associated with the formation of calcium oxalate stones. However, this patient’s urinalysis reveals wedge-shaped crystals, which is more consistent with the presentation of calcium phosphate stones.
